citeinfo.title: Sleepers River Laboratory Information
citeinfo.othercit: This metadata file describes 1 of the 6 data tables published together (see Larger Work section).

citeinfo.title: Aqueous chemistry database, Sleepers River Research Watershed, Danville, Vermont, 1991-2018

descript.abstract: Eighteen different laboratories contributed to the chemistry and isotope database of the Sleepers River project during its nearly 30-year duration. This file serves as a central repository for the quality metrics on these data, including accuracy, precision, and limits of detection. Various methods were used to assimilate the data including direct communication with the laboratories, published papers and reports, and substituting industry standards where the information was unavailable. Each unique combination of laboratory, analyte, and analytical method has its own line in the table, often with annotated comments that elaborate on sources and/or give references.
descript.purpose: It was efficient to present this information in a compact way in a dedicated file, thereby avoiding several columns of repetitive information in the main chemistry file.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.
idinfo.datacred: U.S. Geological Survey Land Change Science

attracc.attraccr: This table presents analytical method accuracy and precision for every unique combination of laboratory and analyte reported in "1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv." Accuracy and precision values were assembled using laboratory communications and published methods. When we could not obtain values directly from the laboratory we estimated them using industry standards. Estimated values have been flagged accordingly. See "Process Steps" and "Overview Description" for a detailed description of calculations and data table organization.

dataqual.complete: Dataset is considered complete for the information presented 08/01/1991-12/31/2018.

procstep.procdesc: This comma delimited (CSV) table, "3. Sleepers River Laboratory Information Metadata," summarizes the detection limit (DL), analytical method, method quality-assurance (QA or accuracy), and method quality-control (QC or precision) for every unique combination of laboratory and chemical or isotopic constituent reported in “1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv.” Detection limits were either already embedded in the data originally received from a laboratory or were provided via written communication with the laboratory. In a small number of cases, the detection limit was either unavailable or embedded in the data non-numerically (such as with a "<" symbol). In these cases, detection limits were inferred from the data or from other laboratories using the same method. Median DLs are reported when DLs varied by analytical run or dilution. Because ranges were sometimes wide, the median was thought to better reflect the central tendency of the detection limit. Special circumstances, such as when median DLs are reported rather than single values, DLs are unknown and inferred from other laboratories, or when DLs were originally embedded in the data non-numerically, are noted in the "DL_Comments" column. Note that if a chemical concentration is less than its DL it is reported in “1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv” as the negative DL except for ANC.µeq.L, d13C, d2H, d18O, d15N.NO3, d18O.NO3, 87Sr.86Sr, and Temp.C,which can be measured as negative values and do not have corresponding DLs in this table. Methods were also obtained via written communication with individual laboratories. If the laboratory method used to analyze a given chemical analyte is published, it is referenced in the "Methods_Reference" column and full citations can be found in the "Citations" field under the "Overview Description" section of this metadata file. Accuracy and precision values were obtained either from written communication with individual laboratories or from the laboratory’s published methods. All accuracy values are presented using the metric of either median or mean percent error (PE),depending on the lab, where PE=( |Measured-Actual| / Actual) × 100 unless otherwise noted. For example, some accuracies were originally expressed as plus or minus (±) concentration and they are presented as such in this table. "Measured" and "Actual" refer to the measured or actual QC sample concentration. All precision values are presented using the metric of the coefficient of variation (CV) where CV is calculated for multiple QC samples of a given reference concentration and expressed on a percent basis as CV = (Standard Deviation / Mean) × 100 unless otherwise noted. For example, isotope precision is presented as permil ( ‰). More details about these metrics, such as how they were originally reported by individual laboratories, can be found in the "Accuracy_Precision_Comments" column. If accuracy or precision was unavailable for a given laboratory, analyte, and method, then the most conservative value reported by the other laboratories for that analyte and method was used. If there was no other value for that given analyte and method, then the most conservative value reported in published methods from either the U.S. Geologic Survey (USGS), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA-NERL), or the American Public Health Association (APHA) Standard Methods was used, depending on the source from which a laboratory would most likely have derived its methods. The inferred value was then additionally cross-checked using the National Environmental Methods Index (NEMI). How a given accuracy or precision value was obtained, whether by written communication, published methods, or inference, is described in the "Accuracy_Precision_Comments" column. Any published reference materials used for obtaining these values are also cited in this column. Full citations can again be found in the "Citations" field under the "Overview Description" section of this metadata file. Additional metrics of chemical analysis performance can be found in "4. Sleepers River Interlaboratory Comparison.csv," "5. Sleepers River Replicate Statistics.csv," and "6. Sleepers River Blank Statistics.csv."

enttyp.enttypd: This comma delimited (CSV) file contains data on laboratory reporting limits and analytical method QA/QC. NA denotes no data. NOTE: Software used to open data file may change default column formatting. If opening in Excel, use Data-Import txt to preserve default column formatting.

attr.attrdef: A number corresponding to a laboratory, identified in the “Laboratory” column, at which a given analyte was analyzed. This number is also reported in “1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv” such that every chemical analyte concentration has a corresponding laboratory source.

The laboratory at which a given chemical analyte was analyzed. The laboratory can also be identified using the corresponding number from the "Laboratory_Key" column. This number is also reported in “1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv” such that every chemical analyte concentration has a corresponding laboratory source.
The chemical or isotopic constituent analyzed by a given laboratory. The analyte names reported in this column also appear as column names in “1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv.”

edom.edomvd: Aluminum measured in micrograms per liter (µg/L)
Total monomeric aluminum measured in micrograms per liter (µg/L)
Organic monomeric aluminum measured in micrograms per liter (µg/L)
Acid neutralizing capacity measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
Barium measured in micrograms per liter (µg/L)
Calcium measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
Chloride measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
Carbon 13C/12C isotope mass ratio presented as permil deviation from the Pee Dee Belemnite standard
Hydrogen 2H/1H isotope mass ratio in water, presented as permil deviation from Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (VSMOW)
Oxygen 18O/16O isotope mass ratio in water, presented as permil deviation from Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (VSMOW)
Nitrogen 15N/14N isotope mass ratio in nitrate, presented as permil deviation from atmospheric composition
Oxygen18O/16O isotope mass ratio in nitrate, presented as permil deviation from Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (VSMOW)
Dissolved organic carbon measured in milligrams per liter (mg/L)
Iron measured in micrograms per liter (µg/L)
Potassium measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
Lithium measured in micrograms per liter (µg/L)
Magnesium measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
Manganese measured in micrograms per liter (µg/L)
Sodium measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
Ammonium measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
Nitrate measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
pH unit
Phosphate measured in milligrams per liter (mg/L)
Silicon measured in micromoles per liter (µmol/L)
Sulfate measured in microequivalents per liter (µeq/L)
Specific conductivity measured in microsiemens per centimeter (µS/cm)
Strontium 87Sr/86Sr isotope mass ratio.
Strontium measured in micrograms per liter (µg/L)
Total dissolved nitrogen measured in milligrams per liter (mg/L)
Total dissolved phosphorus measured in milligrams per liter (mg/L)
Temperature measured in degrees celsius (C)
Ultraviolet (UV)-absorbance at 254 nanometers reported in cm-1

attr.attrdef: The laboratory method used to analyze a given chemical analyte.

If the laboratory method reported in the "Analytical_Method" column is published, it is referenced here. Complete citations can be found in the "Supplemental Information" section of this metadata file.
Detection limits (DLs) are summarized for each laboratory, chemical analyte, and analytical method combination.

edom.edomvd: No Data

attr.attrdef: Comments for DLs reported in column "DL" such as when median DLs are reported as opposed to single vales, DLs are unknown and inferred from other laboratories, or when DLs were originally embedded in the data non-numerically. For example, "<DL" was reported instead of an actual value. See comments for details.

edom.edomvd: No Data

attr.attrdef: Accuracy of a given laboratory, method, and analyte combination presented as percent error (PE) where PE=(|Measured Value of QC sample-Actual Value of QC sample| / Actual Value of QC Sample)×100, unless otherwise noted. Either a median or mean PE is reported depending on the laboratory, which is further specified in the "Accuracy_Precision_Comments" column. Unit of measure is percent unless otherwise noted.

Precision of a given laboratory, method, and analyte combination presented as the coefficient of variation (CV) where CV=(Standard Deviation/Mean)×100, unless otherwise noted. CV is calculated for multiple QC samples of a given reference concentration. Unit of measure is percent unless otherwise noted.

Describes how the accuracy and precision values were obtained, whether by written communication, published methods, or inference, and cites references used. Describes if the values were reported differently in their original source. Complete citations can be found in the "Supplemental Information" section of this metadata file.
Count reports the number of records in “1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv” for each given laboratory, analyte, and method combination.
Sample collection date range, as month and year, for a given laboratory, analyte, and method combination.
Describes unusual distribution of samples collected during the Years_Collected date range such as a long gap.

overview.eaover: This file contains information about the laboratories and analytical methods used to analyze chemistry presented in “1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv.” All combinations of laboratory, chemical analyte, and analytical method are reported by row and sorted by analyte, start date of sample collection, and end date of sample collection; except that the most recently used laboratory always appears last for a given analyte. Note that there can be more than one record for each analyte/laboratory combination when methods change as indicated by different applicable date ranges in the “Years_Collected” column. If a given analyte was continuously measured by a laboratory but appears in two rows due to a method change, then those rows are kept consecutive regardless of the sorting logic.

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
